uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools
Interface GeoData

All Known Implementing Classes:
SimpleGeoData, RemoteGeoData, ExpressionGeoData
public interface GeoData

GeoData objects are used in a large number of places throught GeoTools.
The role of a GeoData object is to associate id values with data values.
Examples of use include matching feature ids to data values for thematic mapping, Storing tool tip texts for displaying with features and for providing data to be graphed or otherwise ploted.

GeoData objects can store both text and numeric data, this was done to provide a single interface to columns of data. getText on a numeric GeoData will correctly return a string of that value, getValue on a text geoData however will fail.

In theory, as GeoData is quite a simple interface it should be posible to implement classes that link back to databases through JDBC for example.

The ids stored in the GeoData must match those found in the features to which the data relates, therefor any class that provides for loading spatial data with associated data should provide a method to retreve pre-built GeoData objects.

For example, the ShapeFileReader class provides the following:
public GeoData readData(int col) - Provides a GeoData for specified column number
public GeoData readData(String colName) - As above, but looks for the column by name. GeoData[] readData() - Provides an array of GeoDatas for the entrire shapefile

Since:
0.5.0
Author:
James Macgill
See Also:
Theme.setGeoData(uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.GeoData)

          All GeoData objects can have a name associated with them.

Field Detail

MISSING

public static final double MISSING
Most geodata sets contain features for which there is no data, or the data is missing.
In these cases a specific value is often used to represent these special cases.

The static final value MISSING is the default value used by GeoDatas to represent these cases.

See Also:
setMissingValueCode(double), getMissingValueCode()

CHARACTER

public static final int CHARACTER
All geodata have a type - this is particularly important when interfacing with other data sources/formats.
See Also:
setDataType(int), getDataType()

INTEGER

public static final int INTEGER

FLOATING

public static final int FLOATING
Method Detail

getName

public java.lang.String getName()
All GeoData objects can have a name associated with them.
Typicaly the name will match the Column heading from which the data came from.
Names can be important when the GeoData is used in thematic maps as this is the name that will be placed in the key by default.
Returns:
String The name associated with this GeoData.

setName

public void setName(java.lang.String name_)
All GeoData objects can have a name associated with them.
Typicaly the name will match the Column heading from which the data came from.
Names can be important when the GeoData is used in thematic maps as this is the name that will be placed in the key by default.
Parameters:
name_ - The name to be associated with this GeoData.

getValue

public double getValue(int id)
looks up and matches a value to the specifed feature id.
Used for example by shaders to obtain vaules for thematic mapping.
Parameters:
id - An int specifying the feature id to retreve a value for.
Returns:
double The value for the specified id, if no id matches the one given then the value specifed by setMissingValue should be returned.
See Also:
#setMissingValue

getText

public java.lang.String getText(int id)
Looks up and retreves a string for the specifed feature id.
Used for example by the ToolTip feature in Themes to provide tool tip text for each feature.
Parameters:
id - An int specifying the feature to retreve the text for.
Returns:
String A piece of text for the chosen feature id. If no id matches then an empty string should be returned " "

getIds

public java.util.Enumeration getIds()
In order to allow systems to iterate through all of the data contained within the GeoData object this method provides a list of all of the IDs which have associated values stored.
Returns:
Enumeration An enumeration of all of the IDs which can then be iterated through.

setMissingValueCode

public void setMissingValueCode(double mv)
Not all posible ids will have a value stored in the GeoData object, so when a call is made to getValue with an id that is not stored a special value is returned to signify that a value for this id is missing.
By default that value is set to MISSING, however this behavoir can be changed by calling this method with a new value.
Parameters:
mv - A double containing the new value to represent missing data.
See Also:
getMissingValueCode()

getMissingValueCode

public double getMissingValueCode()
Not all posible ids will have a value stored in the GeoData object, so when a call is made to getValue with an id that is not stored a special value is returned to signify that a value for this id is missing.
A call to this method will return the current code in use to represent that situation.
Returns:
double The current value representing missing data.
See Also:
setMissingValueCode(double)

getMax

public double getMax()
A quick statistic relating to the values stored in the GeoData object.
Returns:
double The largest value currently stored in this GeoData. The missingValueCode is not included in this test.

getMin

public double getMin()
A quick statistic relating to the values stored in the GeoData object.
Returns:
double The smallest value currently stored in this GeoData. The missingValueCode is not included in this test.

getSize

public int getSize()
The total number of stored id/value pairs stored in this GeoData.
Returns:
int The number of values stored in this GeoData.

getMissingCount

public int getMissingCount()
The total number of stored values stored in this GeoData which equal the missing value code.
Returns:
int The number of missing values stored in this GeoData.

getDataType

public int getDataType()
Gets the type of data stored in the geodata
